natural solution: Computing the sums of the entries in the first few rows suggestions that the sum of the entries in row $n$ is $2^n$. Indeed, one way to prove this formula is to note that the $k$th entry of the $n$th row is $\binom{n}{k}$ (if we say that the entries in the $n$th row are numbered $k=0,1,\dots,n$).

We have  \[ \binom{n}{0}+\binom{n}{1}+\binom{n}{2}+\dots +\binom{n}{n} = 2^n, \]since both sides calculate the number of ways to choose some subset of $n$ objects. It follows that $f(n)=\log_{10} (2^n)$, which means that $\frac{f(n)}{\log_{10} 2}=\frac{\log_{10} (2^n)}{\log_{10} 2}$.
Applying the change of base formula gives us $\log_2 (2^n)=\boxed{n}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and log :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = log (sum (\<lambda> i. binomial n i) {0..n})"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. log x = ln x / ln 10"
shows  "\<forall> n. f n / log 2 = n"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(n)$ be the base-10 logarithm of the sum of the elements of the $n$th row in Pascal's triangle. Express $\frac{f(n)}{\log_{10} 2}$ in terms of $n$. Recall that Pascal's triangle begins

\begin{tabular}{rccccccccc}
$n=0$:& & & & & 1\\\noalign{\smallskip\smallskip}
$n=1$:& & & & 1 & & 1\\\noalign{\smallskip\smallskip}
$n=2$:& & & 1 & & 2 & & 1\\\noalign{\smallskip\smallskip}
$n=3$:& & 1 & & 3 & & 3 & & 1\\\noalign{\smallskip\smallskip}
$n=4$:& 1 & & 4 & & 6 & & 4 & & 1\\\noalign{\smallskip\smallskip}
& & & & & $\vdots$ & & & &

\end{tabular} The final Answer is n
 ### Proof
 Computing the sums of the entries in the first few rows suggestions that the sum of the entries in row $n$ is $2^n$. Indeed, one way to prove this formula is to note that the $k$th entry of the $n$th row is $\binom{n}{k}$ (if we say that the entries in the $n$th row are numbered $k=0,1,\dots,n$).
 We have  \[ \binom{n}{0}+\binom{n}{1}+\binom{n}{2}+\dots +\binom{n}{n} = 2^n, \]since both sides calculate the number of ways to choose some subset of $n$ objects. It follows that $f(n)=\log_{10} (2^n)$, which means that $\frac{f(n)}{\log_{10} 2}=\frac{\log_{10} (2^n)}{\log_{10} 2}$.
 Applying the change of base formula gives us $\log_2 (2^n)=\boxed{n}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and log :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = log (sum (\<lambda> i. binomial n i) {0..n})"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. log x = ln x / ln 10"
shows  "\<forall> n. f n / log 2 = n"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: The function $f(n)$ is defined as the logarithm base 10 of the sum of the binomial coefficients from 0 to $n$ (i.e., the sum of "$n$ choose $i$" for all $i$ in the range 0 to $n$). Given that the logarithm base 10 of $x$ is equal to the natural logarithm of $x$ divided by the natural logarithm of 10, show that for all $n$, the ratio of $f(n)$ to the logarithm base 10 of 2 equals $n$.

a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

$n=4$:& 1 & & 4 & & 6 & & 4 & & 1\\\noalign{\smallskip\smallskip}
& & & & & $\vdots$ & & & &

\end{tabular} The final Answer is n
 ### Proof
 Computing the sums of the entries in the first few rows suggestions that the sum of the entries in row $n$ is $2^n$. Indeed, one way to prove this formula is to note that the $k$th entry of the $n$th row is $\binom{n}{k}$ (if we say that the entries in the $n$th row are numbered $k=0,1,\dots,n$).
 We have  \[ \binom{n}{0}+\binom{n}{1}+\binom{n}{2}+\dots +\binom{n}{n} = 2^n, \]since both sides calculate the number of ways to choose some subset of $n$ objects. It follows that $f(n)=\log_{10} (2^n)$, which means that $\frac{f(n)}{\log_{10} 2}=\frac{\log_{10} (2^n)}{\log_{10} 2}$.
 Applying the change of base formula gives us $\log_2 (2^n)=\boxed{n}$.
 *)

fixes n :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = log 10 (sum (nth_row_pascal n))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. nth_row_pascal n = map (choose n) [0..n]"

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"

fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"

(* ### Problem
 Let $f(n)$ be the base-10 logarithm of the sum of the elements of the $n$th row in Pascal's triangle. Express $\frac{f(n)}{\log_{10} 2}$ in terms of $n$. Recall that Pascal's triangle begins

& & & & & $\vdots$ & & & &

\end{tabular} The final Answer is n
 ### Proof
 Computing the sums of the entries in the first few rows suggestions that the sum of the entries in row $n$ is $2^n$. Indeed, one way to prove this formula is to note that the $k$th entry of the $n$th row is $\binom{n}{k}$ (if we say that the entries in the $n$th row are numbered $k=0,1,\dots,n$).

 Applying the change of base formula gives us $\log_2 (2^n)=\boxed{n}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "f 0 = 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<Longrightarrow> f n = log 10 (sum (\<lambda> k. binomial n k) {0..n})"
shows  "f n / log 10 2 = n"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A real-valued function $f$ is defined on the natural numbers as follows: $f(0) = 0$ and $f(n) = \log_{10}\left(\sum_{k=0}^{n} {n \choose k}\right)$ for all $n > 0$. Find $f(n)$ divided by $\log_{10}(2)$ for a given $n$. The final answer is $n$.
